Collapsing, localized;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Attempted 2 ECTs but the mid-pack was too hard for the cord to cut all the way to the bottom. Both tests had the cutting cord get stuck ~10cm from the bottom of the wind-packed mid-layer. Performed tests anyway and both times there was failure on the ground across the block and a fracture in the mid-pack.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: With persistent cold temperatures, lots of faceting in the upper snowpack. Did not observe any buried SH. Ridgeline start zones scoured, some extended start zones are filled in lower.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: pit done at base of steep slope at NW end of Blueberry Knoll

New snow was about 3' in the gut, with about 1-3'' of wind texture on top. Under the wind texture was about 2-3'' of softer semi sugary snow with mostly firm snow underneath. The new snow/old snow interface seemed to be well bonded with and it was difficult to distinguish the two different layers other than a slight density change.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Two people jumped on the top of this small test slope which resulted in a huge WHUMP, meter deep crack that propagated 50 ft on either side of us, and moved 4" downslope before stopping. **The ECTPV failed at the ground in the basal facets when we gently removed probes after isolating the column.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
We skied slope;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Recent widespread persistent slab avalanche cycle 11/7-8 with storm load, 10" low density at 3000'. Recent remotely triggered avalanches 11/8-9. Improved stability, but poor structure will still allow for small to large human-triggered avalanches possible in specific locations on slopes 30 degrees and steeper. This PWL will continue to be problematic for a long time and re-activated with significant loading. Variable stability in tests today points toward slowly increased stability and is also suspected to be due to a lack of consistent cohesion in the slab. The weak layer appears to have high continuity.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Rain crust did not exist 50 vertical feet higher at the point.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Snowpit location was in a relatively wind sheltered area. Above the snowpit location, much of the east facing terrain was significantly wind affected/ 1F snow/ from the recent storm and not optimal for skiing. It seemed like all other aspects around the Mt. Henderson area (S, W and N) had less surface wind affect.
No avalanche activity observed.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We found the buried November 5 rain crust throughout our trip at all elevations and aspects, from Dry Lake up to 9800ft. It was widespread, 4-6mm thick, and stout yet collapsible under our weight. Also noted a V layer 50cm down. Snow height ranged 30cm at Dry Lake to 70-80cm deep in wind-sheltered locations near the top of Bitch Creek.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Collapsing, localized; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
We experienced 3 significant collapses- all 10m in diameter or larger, and the group of friends we met up with reported another 5 other significant collapses. These collapses were during repeatedly recycling the same skin track.
On a nearby NE aspect around 9100' (on Miller Ridge )we were finding a HS 70-80cms, and also had one significant collapse there too.
No avalanche activity to report. Minimal wind effect of new snow, great early season skiing on certain slopes above 9k'.
This pit was dug as part of CSU Geoscience research

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 2-3' of light density snow filled into the school bus main gully, on top of old 1-2' tall sustraugi snow, from the wind event the weekend of 11/4-11/6 which had winds an estimated 50 constant to 70mph gusts. Most of the 15'' of snow from 11/1& 11/2 had been completely blown away from these extreme winds. The new snow was light density pow with slight wind kissed surface, but more so loading from the SE from the storm days of 11/7-11/9. The new snow had hardly become a slab, if a slab at all.

0-50 cm is the old snow from October and early Nov, it is dense and you can make a snowball with it. 50-70 cm has various layers that have graupel mixed into the snow. There are no obvious graupel layers. We did a CT and ECT. No notable results. All ECTN and CT's were Q2&3. It is a solid and strong snowpack. Our main concern is what will happen with the surface snow (1) it can easily be drifted by winds (2) it will easily facet if we have any period of dry weather.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Observed human triggered cornices which created new snow avalanches on north facing slopes skiers right of West Bowl in the top layer of the new snow. Noted small new snow slides on approach on wind drifted southeast aspects. Pit was an 8 using GCS scale. 4mm graupel at 80cm from the ground stubborn shear after ECTX.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank;
Cracking; We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This snowprofile shows a thick layer of windblown RG and DF lying on a thick mass of MFpc. RG are faceting above this mass forming a weaker layer. The snowpack is generally dry until 110cm down where it turns moist. This shows a healing Sg problem to this point as the pack is slowly freezing through. Although the Swd on top is found in the ECT and CT tests, it is not easily reactive and is generally a BRK fracture characteristic.
Pit was dug below a large bluff in a wind drift for the purposes of assessment profiles. Actual aspect of slope below is NE.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: solid PPrm crust, pit dug in as sheltered of a spot as I could find on a WSW aspect

Se realizo un perfil en zonas próxima al lugar de campamento, buscando un manto con una profundidad homogénea que se condice con el lugar donde nos desplazamos, transitamos y realizamos la actividad profesional, en una zona segura alejada de posibles desprendimientos, verificando la altura, el ángulo y la ladera, considerando las condiciones del cielo, temperatura del aire, profundidad del manto, presión del manto con la bota, realizando el perfil y trabajando en la zona lateral con sombras, identificando capas con nuestras mano sin guantes, una vez identificada se realizaron los diferentes test de resistencia, para el análisis de cada capa, en este caso se practicó con guantes, se pudo medir el tamaño de cada capa, dureza, tipo de granos, temperaturas. Posterior a eso en la cara frontal del perfil realizamos el test de compresión aislando una columna de 30x30 centímetros, el cual tuvo un resultado CT-H 24, Q3 a 65 centímetros, definiendo que se realizó el test de compresión y al golpe 24 se fracturo, pero la carga no logro cruzar en una sola, siendo una cizalla bastante irregular lo que le da la categoría ya mencionada. El test da un resultado positivo ya que concluimos que el manto estaba bastante homogénea y compactado, no encontrando capas débiles en el interior del manto, siendo solo la superficial en los primeros veinte centímetros, manteniéndose hacia abajo entre cuchillo y lápiz. Definitivamente es un pronóstico favorable ya que nos desplazaríamos con raquetas, en todo momento se va gestionando el riesgo lo que nos daba seguridad en el trayecto.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Facets at ground are around tussock. In other places, basal ice. Low concern. Graupel layer variable across slope in distribution and thickness. Generally very stable pack. Breakable crust is the only concern for poor skiing. With forecasted clear weather in the next few days, monitor pack for faceting occurring from very cold temps and steep gradient

Ectn11@115 around IFrc this layer and test result is of concern with incoming Nw storm 22/07/17-18 with forecasted precip amounts greater than 50cm and potential for large volume of wind loading
light snow saltation

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Poor pit location;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Muy próximo al perfil anterior y que por un error al ubicarlo, este pozo terminó con la misma HS que el pozo anterior aún así teniendo una nevada previa y nieve acumulada por viento. Sin embargo, la distribución de capas es idéntica al anterior así que decidimos continuarlo.
Very close the previous profile and with a mistake when choosing the location, this profile ended up with the same HS of the other pit, despite of having two new layers of fresh snow. Nonetheless we decided to continue with it due to the fact that layers distribution was identical to the first one.
